app.lem: 江神子·乙卯正月二十日夜記夢
app.rdg:
To the tune “River God”
This tune also goes by the name “River Town”, and “River Town” is the tune name for another of Su Shi’s poems in the collection, “Hunting in Mizhou”.—"Recording the Dream on the Night of the Twentieth of the First Month of 1075 CE"

For ten years, the dead and the living have been separated by a vast and obscure distance
Su Shi’s first wife, Wang Fu, died in 1065 CE; by the time he wrote this song, it had been ten years since her death..
I forced myself not to think of you,
But it is hard for me to forget.

The solitary grave, a thousand miles away,
Wang Fu was buried in Meizhou, far away from Su Shi’s current location in Mizhou.
Nowhere to speak about this loneliness and misery of mine.
Even if we could meet, you would not recognize me.

Dust all over my face
During the Song Dynasty, people traveled by horse and carriage, and “Dust all over my face” implies that the poet traveled a lot during the ten years. It also suggests that a lot had happened to him, and that complicated life experiences had made the older poet very different from his younger self.,
and the hair at my temples like frost.
Yesterday night, in a mournful dream, I suddenly returned to my hometown.
you were combing your hair and doing your makeup.
We gazed at each other, speechless;
only thousands of lines of tears coursed down.
I know your heart breaks for me year after year
upon the hill with the low pine trees.
